case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax v. Ratilal Nathalal

facts.text: This is an appeal under Section 66A of the Indian Income-tax Act from the judgment of the High Court of Bombay given on a reference to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under Section 66 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Jagannadhadas, J. This is an appeal under Section 66A of the Indian Income-tax Act from the judgment of the High Court of Bombay given on a reference to it by the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal under Section 66 of the Act.

facts.text: The proceedings relate to the four assessment years, 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45, and 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: The proceedings relate to the four assessment years, 1942-43, 1943-44, 1944-45, and 1945-46, and arise under the following circumstances There was a Hindu undivided family consisting of one

facts.text: There was a Hindu undivided family consisting of Ramjibhai, his son Ratilal Nathalal (respondent), Ramjibhai's wife Kamlawanti, Ratilal's wife Kantabai, and Ramjibhai's unmarried daughter Pushpa.

anchor.surface_text: There was a Hindu undivided family consisting of one  1 Ramjibhai,  2  his son, Ratilal Nathalal - the respondent before us,  3  Ramjibhais wife, kamlawanti,  4  Ratilals wife, Kantabai, and  5  Ramjibhais unmarried daughter, Pushpa.

facts.text: On July 27, 1933, Ramjibhai and Ratilal, the sole coparceners of the Hindu undivided family, executed a trust deed in respect of four items of house property belonging to the joint family.

anchor.surface_text: On the July 27, 1933, Ramjibhai and Ratilal, who were the sole companyarceners, at the time, of the said Hindu undivided family, executed a trust deed in respect of four items of house property belonging to the joint family, which owned at the time and

facts.text: The joint family owned other properties besides the four items settled on trust.

anchor.surface_text: companytinued to own other properties also. The effect of the trust deed was that the income of the property settled on trust was to be enjoyed by Ramjibhai during his lifetime, and that after his death the said income was to be enjoyed by the respondent, Ratilal, alone,

facts.text: The trust deed provided that income of the property was to be enjoyed by Ramjibhai during his lifetime.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the trust deed was that the income of the property settled on trust was to be enjoyed by Ramjibhai during his lifetime, and that after his death the said income was to be enjoyed by the respondent, Ratilal, alone, with a right of residence provided in favour of his mother, Kamlawanti,

facts.text: After Ramjibhai's death, the income was to be enjoyed by Ratilal alone, with right of residence to Kamlawanti in part of one house.

anchor.surface_text: and that after his death the said income was to be enjoyed by the respondent, Ratilal, alone, with a right of residence provided in favour of his mother, Kamlawanti, in a part of one of the houses companyprised in the trust deed.

facts.text: After Ratilal's death, income to be enjoyed by Kantabai and natural born sons in existence at death of survivor of Ramjibhai and Ratilal.

anchor.surface_text: After the death of the respondent Ratilal, the income is to be enjoyed by his wife, Kantabai, and the natural born sons in existence at the time of the death of the survivor of Ramjibhai and Ratilal. There was an express power of revocation of the trust deed reserved to the said Ramjibhai

facts.text: The trust deed reserved express power of revocation to Ramjibhai.

anchor.surface_text: There was an express power of revocation of the trust deed reserved to the said Ramjibhai by a specific clause therein.

facts.text: Ramjibhai enjoyed the income during his lifetime, assessed as joint family income under Section 16(1)(c) and added to other joint family income, without dispute.

anchor.surface_text: Ramjibhai enjoyed the income during his lifetime but the said income was being assessed as joint family income under Section 16 1  c  of the Act and as an addition to the other admitted joint family income.

facts.text: Section 16 of the Indian Income-tax Act was modified in 1939.

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the Indian Income-tax Act was modified in 1939 and clause  c  of sub-section  1  thereof as amended is as follows In companyputing the total income of an assessee - all income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition whether revocable or number,

facts.text: Ramjibhai died on July 23, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: Ramjibhai died on the July 23, 1940. The Income-tax authorities companytinued, after the death of Ramjibhai, to assess the income, in the hands of the respondent arising from the properties settled as the family income.

facts.text: After Ramjibhai's death, Income-tax authorities assessed the income from trust properties in hands of respondent Ratilal as family income.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax authorities companytinued, after the death of Ramjibhai, to assess the income, in the hands of the respondent arising from the properties settled as the family income. The respondent objected on the ground that under the terms of the settlement it was only his individual income

facts.text: Respondent objected that income was his individual income and Section 16(1)(c) had no application.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent objected on the ground that under the terms of the settlement it was only his individual income and that Section 16 1  c  had numberapplication to him. The Income-tax authorities overruled this companytention.

facts.text: Income-tax authorities overruled respondent's contention.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax authorities overruled this companytention. The assessee appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal but by order dated the March 16, 1950, it companyfirmed the view taken by the Income-tax authorities.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal confirmed the view of Income-tax authorities by order dated March 16, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal but by order dated the March 16, 1950, it companyfirmed the view taken by the Income-tax authorities. Thereupon at the instance of the respondent, the Tribunal stated a case to the High Court of Bombay under Section 66 1  of the Act

facts.text: Tribunal stated a case to High Court of Bombay under Section 66(1) and referred the question: Whether income from trust property liable to be included in income of assessee Hindu undivided family?

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon at the instance of the respondent, the Tribunal stated a case to the High Court of Bombay under Section 66 1  of the Act and referred the following question for its decision Whether in the circumstances of the case and on the true companystruction of the settlement deed, is the income

facts.text: Assessee contended before High Court that settlor was not Hindu undivided family but Ramjibhai and Ratilal as individuals.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the assessee before the High Court was two-fold  1  that the settlor under the trust deed was number the Hindu undivided family as the Income-tax authorities were inclined to hold, but that the settlement was by two individual male members of the family, viz., Ramjibhai and Ratilal

facts.text: High Court held that Ramjibhai and Ratilal executed trust deed as sole coparceners representing the Hindu undivided family.

anchor.surface_text: On the first point, the learned Judges held against the assessees companytention. In their view the two individuals, Ramjibhai and Ratilal, executed the trust deed number in their individual capacity but as the sole companyarceners of the Hindu undivided family and as representing the said family.

facts.text: High Court held that income received by Ratilal after Ramjibhai's death is his individual income, not joint family income.

anchor.surface_text: On the second point, however, they held in favour of the assessee and against the Commissioner. ... The view taken by the High Court that the settlement deed was executed by both Ramjibhai and Ratilal on behalf of the Hindu undivided family as the settlor has number been disputed before us on either side.

facts.text: The view that settlor was Hindu undivided family is not disputed before Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court that the settlement deed was executed by both Ramjibhai and Ratilal on behalf of the Hindu undivided family as the settlor has number been disputed before us on either side. The sole question for our companysideration is whether or number the view taken by the High Court on the second point is right.

concepts.interpretation: Income from revocable settlement by HUF deemed income of HUF settlor; post-death income to coparcener not deemed retransfer to HUF as HUF is distinct unit from individual coparceners
concepts.unlisted_description: Deems income from revocable settlements/dispositions as settlor's income; provisos define revocable and settlor

anchor.surface_text: Section 16 of the Indian Income-tax Act was modified in 1939 and clause  c  of sub-section  1  thereof as amended is as follows In companyputing the total income of an assessee - all income arising to any person by virtue of a settlement or disposition whether revocable or number, and whether effected before or after the companymencement of the Indian Income-tax  Amendment  Act, 1939  VII of 1939 , from assets remaining the property of the settlor or disponer, shall be deemed to be income of the settlor or disponer, and all income arising to any person by virtue of a revocable transfer of assets shall be deemed to be income of the transferor Provided that for the purposes of this clause a settlement, disposition or transfer shall be deemed to be revocable if it companytains any provision for the retransfer directly or indirectly of the income or assets to the settlor, disponer or transferor, or in any way gives the settlor, disponer or transferor a right to reassume power directly or indirectly over the income or assets Provided further that the expression settlement or disposition shall for the purposes of this clause include any disposition, trust, companyenant, agreement, or arrangement, and the expression settlor or disponer in relation to a settlement or disposition shall include any person by whom the settlement or disposition was made

concepts.interpretation: Full text quoted and applied to determine if income post-settlor's death to beneficiary coparcener triggers deeming provision via provisos

concepts.interpretation: HUF acts as distinct juristic unit through coparceners; income directed to individual coparcener not retransfer to HUF
concepts.unlisted_description: Joint family entity in Hindu law capable of being settlor in trust; distinct from its coparcenary members

anchor.surface_text: sole companyarceners, at the time, of the said Hindu undivided family, executed a trust deed in respect of four items of house property belonging to the joint family

concepts.interpretation: Coparceners represent HUF in executing deeds but HUF remains separate unit; benefit to coparcener individually not to HUF
concepts.unlisted_description: Members with right to demand partition in HUF; act on behalf of HUF

anchor.surface_text: the companytention on behalf of the appellant that what was intended under the terms of the trust deed as the individual income of the respondent Ratilal becomes the joint family income by a process of successive application of the fictions enacted in the last portion of clause  c  of Section 16 1

concepts.interpretation: Fictions in S.16(1)(c) and provisos cannot be successively applied to deem individual income as HUF income where beneficiary not treated consistently as settlor
concepts.unlisted_description: Deeming provisions in tax statute limited to their terms; cannot extend beyond logical application

arguments.claim: income which Ratilal receives after the death of Ramjibhai is received by him not on behalf of the joint family but in his own individual capacity; receives benefit in different capacity; trust deed does not benefit joint family

anchor.surface_text: Now the settlement of this property was made by Ramjibhai and Ratilal number in their individual capacity but as members of the joint family and as representing that family. It is clear on this trust deed that the income which Ratilal receives after the death of Ramjibhai is received by him number on behalf of the joint family but in his own individual capacity. Ratilal alienated the property in one capacity and he receives the benefit under the trust deed in an altogether different capacity. Therefore it cannot be stated that this trust deed in any way benefits the joint family.

holdings.text: The settlement deed was executed by both Ramjibhai and Ratilal on behalf of the Hindu undivided family as the settlor

anchor.surface_text: The view taken by the High Court that the settlement deed was executed by both Ramjibhai and Ratilal on behalf of the Hindu undivided family as the settlor has not been disputed before us on either side.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court finding accepted as not disputed by either side

holdings.text: the Hindu undivided family is a unit independent of and larger than the two coparceners and is not merely a collection of the individuals who acted on its behalf
holdings.reasoning_summary: HUF distinct from coparceners who represent it, preventing individual treatment under proviso

holdings.text: the second proviso which treats one out of a group of settlors as the settlor cannot come into operation
holdings.reasoning_summary: Inapplicable when settlor is HUF, not group of individuals

holdings.text: the provision in the settlement deed giving the income back to Ratilal, even if it be take as a retransfer of the income, cannot be treated as such retransfer to the original settlor, viz., the Hindu undivided family
holdings.reasoning_summary: Retransfer to individual coparcener not to HUF settlor

holdings.text: the last portion of clause c of Section 16 1 does not come into operation
holdings.reasoning_summary: No revocable transfer triggered due to absence of retransfer to settlor HUF

holdings.text: the contention on behalf of the appellant that what was intended under the terms of the trust deed as the individual income of the respondent Ratilal becomes the joint family income by a process of successive application of the fictions enacted in the last portion of clause c of Section 16 1 , and the two provisos thereto, cannot be accepted
holdings.reasoning_summary: Successive deeming fictions fail due to inconsistent treatment of settlor and lack of retransfer to HUF; upholds High Court that income is individual

The coparcener concept, distinguishing individual benefits from HUF despite representation in deeds, addresses the issue of includibility of trust property income in the assessee's income based on settlement deed construction.
The coparcener concept addresses the second point evaluated by the High Court regarding separation of individual and HUF benefits in trust contexts.
The concept that fictions cannot be successively applied grounds the holding that the second proviso (treating one settlor out of group as settlor) cannot come into operation.
The concept that fictions cannot be successively applied grounds the holding that the last portion of clause (c) of Section 16(1) does not come into operation.
The statutory fiction concept on non-successive fictions addresses the second point whose High Court view is questioned in i2.

The concept describes fictions in S.16(1)(c) and provisos that cannot be successively applied to deem individual income as HUF income, directly addressing the issue of whether individual income becomes joint family income by successive application.
